articles.title: Why you need to get regular eye exams
articles.description: Human beings are a sight based species – We depend on our eyesight for many things from movement to empathizing with others by recognizing their facial expressions it is therefore important to take care of our eyesight.
articles.markdown:
Human beings are a sight based species – We depend on our eyesight for many things from movement to empathizing with others by recognizing their facial expressions it is therefore important to take care of our eyesight. Regular eye testing is an integral part to proper eye care and in this article we are going to look at five reasons why you should get your eyes tested regularly.


But before we get into it I would like to discuss how frequently you need to get your eyes checked, the NSH advises that you get your eyes checked every two years. We believe the frequency depends on the individual’s risk of developing eye problems – this depends on history of eye disease in the family or whether they have a disease that makes them susceptible to eye diseases. In any case it is advisable that you get your eyes tested at least once a year.


1. The quality of your vision directly affects your everyday life and better vision means a better lifestyle

Neglecting your eyesight to the point deteriorating its quality will mean more challenges you will have to face every day, therefore we must ensure that we look after our eyesight.



2. Going for regular eye checks can help you detect diseases such as cataracts, glaucoma and age related muscular degenerations

With regular eye checks you will be able to detect eye diseases such as glaucoma (a disease that deteriorates the condition of your optic nerves) which do not offer any warning signs before permanently affecting your vision.



3. Your optometrist could identify broader health conditions with symptoms that affect your eyes

Problems such as diabetes and high blood pressure could affect your eyes and your optometrist could help you identify these diseases early during a routine eye check and help you get attention for the problem sooner.



4. Eye checks for students can help improve their performance in class and extracurricular activities

This is because around 80% of the things children have to understand both in and out of class require good eyesight. Regular eye checks for children can also help you recognize eye complications like lazy eye and short sightedness early. And because children cannot tell what good vision is like they are less likely to complain about eye problems so regular eye checks can help them perform better in their everyday life.



5. Glaucoma does not show any warning signs until it’s too late

Glaucoma the disease that affects your optic nerves doesn’t show any symptoms or warning signs and patients who suffer from this condition often find out that they have it after the disease has caused permanent damage to the patients sights. Regular eye examination can help you identify this disease before it reaches this terrible condition.

articles.title: Signs you may need to get glasses
articles.description: Many aspects of day to day life require good vision, so we must be on the lookout for signs of vision loss or degradation. The most effective way to know if you need glasses is too see an optometrist and have them conduct a comprehensive eye exam on you but in the mean-time look out these signs of warning and if you are experiencing any of them please consider seeing an optometrist to have it checked out;
articles.markdown:
Many aspects of day to day life require good vision, so we must be on the lookout for signs of vision loss or degradation. The most effective way to know if you need glasses is too see an optometrist and have them conduct a comprehensive eye exam on you but in the mean-time look out these signs of warning and if you are experiencing any of them please consider seeing an optometrist to have it checked out;


1. Trouble reading road sign:

Failing to read a road sign can be a symptom of myopia (shortsightedness) this means you have trouble seeing things far from while you have no problem seeing close by objects. Another reason you may not be able to read road signs is Astigmatism which involves the uneven distribution of light in the cornea. Astigmatism can be corrected with glasses.



2. Frequent headaches:

This is sometimes cause by failure of the mechanism in the mechanism in the eye that helps your lens and cornea focus on image, leaving the smaller muscles in your eye to pick up the slack. This means you squint a lot and that causes headaches so if you notice frequent headaches you may need to see an eye doctor.



3. Squinting, frowning, eye aches and headaches:

Squinting, frowning, headaches and other forms of discomfort with your eyes can be serious signs that something is wrong and you will have to seek advice from an optometrist to find out what is causing it. This can be mild or severe discomfort, all the same it is a good idea to get your eyesight checked – registries by the American National Eye Institution have fond that over 60% of the people in the world need eye treatment, luckily 80% of eye problems are correctable and so it is important to get your eyes examined.



4. Seeing Halos:

These halos appear around objects and are more visible in the dark. They can be early warning signs for cataracts, clouding of the eye lens which is the leading cause of vision loss. Cataracts can be treated by implanting and intra ocular lens (IOL).



5. Blurred Vision:

Blurred vision could be a sign of either nearsightedness or farsightedness which means you have trouble seeing items far from you or near you. If you have blurry vision when seeing things both near and far, blurry vision can be a sign of astigmatism which is a common condition that involves curvature of the eye lens or cornea. If you have blurry vision we advise resting your eyes and seeing an optometrist.



6. Wavy Vision:

If items around you with straight edges often suddenly seem wavy as though they are immersed in water or if colors look dull you may be experiencing macular degeneration, wearing of the central portion of the cornea which is a leading cause of vision loss.



7. Difficulty working on the computer:

Often when a person has trouble working in the computer it means they may be suffering from farsightedness which is the condition in which a person has trouble seeing things close to them.

articles.title: How to take good care of your eyes
articles.description: Taking good care of your eyes is an obvious necessity we depend on our eyes to be able to do many of the things in our daily lives but the how part may not be that obvious. How do I take good care of my eyes and ensure that I prevent any illnesses that may cause vision loss? In this article we will walk you through some of the things you can do to take care of your eyes and ensure that you maintain good eyesight.
articles.markdown:
Taking good care of your eyes is an obvious necessity we depend on our eyes to be able to do many of the things in our daily lives but the how part may not be that obvious. How do I take good care of my eyes and ensure that I prevent any illnesses that may cause vision loss? In this article we will walk you through some of the things you can do to take care of your eyes and ensure that you maintain good eyesight.


Don’t rub your eyes :

We touch a lot of things with our hands and that means they are exposed to a lot of dust and bacteria and when you rub your eyes you risk passing that dirt to them and potentially infecting or irritating them. Rubbing your eyes can become a very challenging habit to let go of but try to avoid it as much as you can to protect your eyes.



Eat Healthy :

To make sure that your eyes get all the nutrients they need for you to have healthy eyesight ensure that your diet includes lots of fruits and vegetables particularly deep green and yellow leafy vegetables like spinach and kale. Also eat fish rich in omega-3 fatty acids, such fish is often oily like salmon and tuna. Nuts, beans, eggs and other non-meat sources of protein are also good for your eyes. More foods to include in your diet that are good for your eyes are; citrus fruits like oranges, port and oysters to name a few.



Don’t smoke:

Smoking increases your likelihood to develop age related macular degeneration and cataracts which can greatly harm your vision over time. Smoking is particularly challenging habit to let go of but do it can be very beneficial to your health in the long run, so if you have tried to quit before and failed don’t stop trying you are more likely to succeed if you keep trying ;).



Put on some sunglasses :

The sun releases Ultraviolet (UV) light which in large amounts can boost you chances of cataracts and muscular degeneration. Make sure you get a pair that blocks 99% to 100% of UV light.



Take breaks from electronic screens :

Staring at electronic screens for too long may increase; eyestrain, trouble focusing at a distance and dry eyes. To protect your eyes align the top of your computer screen to be slightly below your eyes that way you are looking slightly down at the screen and you don’t strain your eyes as much. Make sure to take a break from working on your computer at least every 2 hours.



Observe the 20-20-20 rule :

Look away from your computer screen every 20 minutes and fix your gaze on an object 20 feet away (6 meters) for 20 seconds. This helps you rest your eyes.



Get enough sleep:

Just like any other part of your body your eyes need to rest and that happens when you sleep, your entire body gets a reset in preparation for the next day.



Keep your environment clean :

Finally, keep your environment clean to make sure that there isn’t any dirt or duct around that may irritate your eyes. Make sure you change your beddings and towels regularly and maintain a good level of personal hygiene to ensure that protect your eyesight and your general wellbeing.
